greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = Sum_{d dividing n} tau(d)^3 = (Sum_{d dividing n} tau(d))^2.
comment: When n = p^e is a prime power, we have the corollary a(n) = Sum_{r=1..e+1} r^3 = (Sum_{r=1..e+1} r)^2, i.e. A000537(n) = (A000217(n))^2.
3^A001221(n) always divides a(n) except if n > 1 and included in A000578. - _Enrique Pérez Herrero_, Jul 12 2010
reference: T. M. Apostol, Introduction to Analytic Number Theory, Springer-Verlag, 1976, page 47.
J.-M. De Koninck & A.Mercier, 1001 Problèmes en Théorie Classique Des Nombres, Problem 562, pp. 75, 265; Ellipses Paris 2004.
W. J. LeVeque, Topics in Number Theory. Addison-Wesley, Reading, MA, 2 vols., 1956, Vol. 1, p. 85, Problem 2.
William J. LeVeque, Fundamentals of Number Theory, Dover Publications Inc, 1977, p. 125.
Joe Roberts, The Lure of Integers, MAA, 1992, Integer 3, pages 8-9.
J. V. Uspensky and M. A. Heaslet, Elementary Number Theory, McGraw-Hill, NY, 1939, p. 84.
link: Seiichi Manyama, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000 (terms 1..1000 from Enrique Pérez Herrero)
maple: with(numtheory); f:=proc(n) local t1; t1:=divisors(n); add(sigma[0](i), i in t1)^2; end;
mathematica: tau[1,n_Integer] := 1; SetAttributes[tau, Listable]; tau[k_Integer,n_Integer] := Plus@@(tau[k-1,Divisors[n]]); A097988[n_] := tau[3,n]^2; Table[A097988[n], {n, 100}] (* _Enrique Pérez Herrero_, Jul 12 2010 *)
a[n_] := DivisorSum[n, DivisorSigma[0, #]&]^2; Array[a, 100] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Dec 02 2015 *)
f[p_, e_] := ((e+1)*(e+2)/2)^2; a[1] = 1; a[n_] := Times @@ f @@@ FactorInteger[n]; Array[a, 100] (* _Amiram Eldar_, Sep 20 2020 *)
results.author: _Lekraj Beedassy_, Sep 07 2004
ext: Entry revised by _N. J. A. Sloane_, May 22 2012
